newsitem.title: USA: NYMEX natgas futures called much higher on weather.
newsitem.headline: NYMEX natgas futures called much higher on weather.

text.p: NYMEX January Henry Hub natgas futures were expected to open significantly higher Monday, as well below-normal temperatures are forecast for many parts of the U.S. this week, industry sources said.
January over-the-counter trading ranged from as low as $3.98 early to $4.10 per million British thermal units following Friday's settlement to the upside at $3.851.
"It's the arctic cold moving in. If cash gets above index, we don't know how high it (Jan) can go," one futures trader said.
Traders speculated that resistance in January was around $4.20. Support was seen in the $3.531-3.565 area, and then $3.19.

In Friday's cash market, Gulf Coast prices climbed 20 cents to near $3.60. Midcontinent prices were 10-15 cents higher in the mid-$3.40s. New York city gate gas was talked five to 10 cents higher at about $4.05-4.10.

Contributing to the rally was news that a few nuclear plants were shut down. The New York Power Authority's 832 megawatt (MW) Fitzpatrick unit, Duke Power's 1,129 MW Catawba 2 in South Carolina, and Southern Co's 822 MW Farley 2 in Alabama, were all shut over the weekend.
Also, PECO Energy's 1,055 MW Limerick 2 unit in Pennsylvania, was reduced to about 15 percent of capacity to correct an exhaust gas problem.
